description: Hero Council - A curated selection of influential figures for daily wisdom and guidance

heroes.name: Marcus Aurelius
heroes.title: Philosopher Emperor
principles: Control what you can control; accept what you cannot.
The obstacle is the way - use adversity as fuel.
Begin each day by telling yourself: I shall meet interference.
Your thoughts shape your reality - choose them wisely.
Focus on the present moment; past and future are illusions.

insightTemplate.morningGreeting: The Emperor reminds you: What stands in the way becomes the way.
insightTemplate.focusAdvice: Focus only on what is within your control today.
insightTemplate.challengeReframe: See obstacles not as barriers but as opportunities for growth.
insightTemplate.actionPrompt: What one thing can you control completely today?
insightTemplate.closingWisdom: Waste no more time arguing what a good person should be. Be one.

actions: Identify one thing outside your control today and release it.
Reframe today's biggest challenge as an opportunity.
Spend 5 minutes in morning reflection before checking your phone.
When frustrated, pause and ask: Is this within my control?
Write down three things you're grateful for right now.
ifThens: If I encounter an obstacle, then I will ask: How can this make me stronger?
If I feel anxious, then I will focus only on my next action.
If someone frustrates me, then I will consider their perspective first.
If I wake up unmotivated, then I will start with the smallest possible step.
If my plans fail, then I will adapt rather than despair.
questions: What is within my control right now?
How would my best self handle this situation?
Am I acting from principle or from emotion?
Will this matter in five years?
What would I advise a friend in my situation?

quotes.text: The impediment to action advances action. What stands in the way becomes the way.
You have power over your mind - not outside events. Realize this, and you will find strength.
We suffer more often in imagination than in reality.
Waste no more time arguing about what a good man should be. Be one.

heroes.name: David Goggins
heroes.title: Endurance Athlete & Motivator
principles: Embrace the suck - growth happens in discomfort.
The 40% rule: When your mind says quit, you're only 40% done.
Callous your mind through consistent hard work.
Take souls - outwork everyone who doubts you.
Stay hard - discipline equals freedom.

insightTemplate.morningGreeting: Stay hard! Your mind will quit a thousand times before your body does.
insightTemplate.focusAdvice: When your mind says stop, you are only 40% done. Push through.
insightTemplate.challengeReframe: This discomfort is your teacher. Embrace it.
insightTemplate.actionPrompt: What is the hardest thing you can do today?
insightTemplate.closingWisdom: Nobody cares what you did yesterday. What are you going to do today?

actions: Do one thing today that makes you uncomfortable.
When you want to quit, do 10 more reps/minutes.
Wake up 30 minutes earlier than planned.
Complete your hardest task before noon.
Run that extra mile or lift that extra set.
ifThens: If I want to quit, then I will push for 10 more reps.
If I feel tired, then I will remember: I've survived worse.
If my alarm goes off, then I will get up immediately.
If I make an excuse, then I will counter it with action.
If the workout seems too hard, then that's exactly why I must do it.
questions: Am I giving everything I have, or holding back?
What would the hardest version of me do right now?
Is this discomfort or actual danger?
Who am I when no one is watching?
What will I regret NOT doing today?

quotes.text: You are in danger of living a life so comfortable that you will die without ever realizing your potential.
Motivation is crap. When you're driven, whatever is in front of you will get destroyed.
Don't stop when you're tired. Stop when you're done.
Nobody cares what you did yesterday. What have you done today to get better?

heroes.name: Jocko Willink
heroes.title: Navy SEAL Commander
principles: Discipline equals freedom.
Extreme ownership: own everything in your world.
Default aggressive - take the initiative.
Good. (Turn setbacks into opportunities.)
Detach and assess before reacting.

insightTemplate.morningGreeting: Get after it. Discipline is the path to freedom.
insightTemplate.focusAdvice: Take extreme ownership of everything in your world.
insightTemplate.challengeReframe: Something went wrong? Good. Now you can learn and improve.
insightTemplate.actionPrompt: What can you take ownership of today that you have been avoiding?

actions: Wake up at 4:30 AM and attack the day.
Take ownership of one problem you've been blaming on others.
Make a decision you've been avoiding.
Lead from the front on a difficult task.
Have a difficult conversation you've been postponing.
ifThens: If something goes wrong, then I will say 'Good' and find the opportunity.
If I blame someone else, then I will ask: What could I have done differently?
If I feel overwhelmed, then I will prioritize and execute one thing at a time.
If my alarm goes off, then feet hit the floor immediately.
If I face a problem, then I will take ownership first.
questions: What am I avoiding that I need to face?
Am I leading or waiting to be led?
What would extreme ownership look like here?
Am I making excuses or finding solutions?
What decision am I avoiding?

quotes.text: Discipline equals freedom.
Don't expect to be motivated every day. You must be DRIVEN.
There are no bad teams, only bad leaders.
Get after it.

heroes.name: Seneca
heroes.title: Stoic Philosopher
principles: Begin at once to live, and count each day as a separate life.
We suffer more in imagination than in reality.
Time is our most precious resource - waste nothing.
Rehearse adversity to be prepared when it arrives.
Associate with people who will make you better.

insightTemplate.morningGreeting: Seneca reminds you: Most of what we fear never comes to pass.
insightTemplate.focusAdvice: Value your time above all else - it is your only truly finite resource.
insightTemplate.challengeReframe: The anxiety you feel is imagination, not reality.
insightTemplate.actionPrompt: What would you do today if you knew this was your last?
insightTemplate.closingWisdom: It is not that we have a short time to live, but that we waste a lot of it.

actions: Practice negative visualization - imagine losing what you value.
Spend 15 minutes preparing for tomorrow's challenges.
Audit how you spent yesterday - was it meaningful?
Write a letter to yourself 10 years from now.
Fast from one luxury today to appreciate it more.
ifThens: If I worry about the future, then I will prepare for the worst and act in the present.
If I feel comfortable, then I will seek voluntary discomfort.
If I waste time, then I will treat tomorrow as borrowed time.
If afraid, then I will do the thing I fear.
If angry, then I will wait before responding.
questions: If today were my last, would I be satisfied with how I spent it?
What am I afraid of that I need to confront?
Am I living or merely existing?
What would I do differently if time were limited?
Am I surrounding myself with people who elevate me?

quotes.text: It is not that we have a short time to live, but that we waste a lot of it.
Difficulties strengthen the mind, as labor does the body.
We suffer more often in imagination than in reality.
Begin at once to live, and count each separate day as a separate life.

heroes.name: Eliud Kipchoge
heroes.title: Marathon World Record Holder
principles: No human is limited.
Consistency is the key to success - show up every day.
The mind is the athlete - train it as hard as the body.
Run with joy - suffering is optional.
Patience in training, aggression in racing.

insightTemplate.morningGreeting: No human is limited. Run with joy today.
insightTemplate.focusAdvice: Focus on the process, not the outcome. Consistency wins.
insightTemplate.challengeReframe: The discomfort you feel is growth. Smile through it.
insightTemplate.actionPrompt: What small improvement can you make in today's training?
insightTemplate.closingWisdom: Only the disciplined ones are free in life.

actions: Run or train with a smile today.
Focus on the process, not the outcome.
Do your easy runs truly easy.
Write in a training journal after your workout.
Rest as deliberately as you train.
ifThens: If the workout feels hard, then I will smile and lean into it.
If I miss a training day, then I will not dwell - I will show up tomorrow.
If I feel impatient for results, then I will trust the process.
If racing or competing, then I will give everything and hold nothing back.
If doubts arise, then I will remind myself: no human is limited.
questions: Am I enjoying the process or just chasing the outcome?
Am I being consistent or searching for shortcuts?
Is my mind as trained as my body?
Am I running my own race or comparing to others?
What small improvement can I make today?

quotes.text: No human is limited.
I don't know where the limits are, but I would like to go there.
Only the disciplined ones are free in life.
Run with your heart, not your legs.
